#Text=Make Sesame Oil
#Text=Sesame oil is a flavorful cooking oil that is rich in calcium , copper , zinc , iron , and magnesium .
#Text=It is also very beneficial for overall skin health because of these minerals .
#Text=To make sesame oil at home , toast the seeds until they are golden brown , mix them with a cooking oil of your choice , and blend up the seeds .
#Text=At this point , the sesame oil forms on the top of the ingredients .
#Text=Refrigerate your sesame oil for up to 2 years so you can easily use it to cook many delicious meals .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Toasting the Seeds
#Text=Use about 3 cups ( 710 g ) of seeds to make 1 cup ( 237 mL ) of oil .
#Text=Use more or less sesame seeds based on how much you have available and how much oil you want to yield .
#Text=Making 1 cup ( 237 mL ) of sesame oil is a good amount for general cooking and skincare needs .
#Text=If you want to make a lot in advance , double or triple the amount of sesame seeds .
#Text=Bake the sesame seeds at for an effortless option .
#Text=To do this , spread the seeds across a baking sheet .
#Text=Then , place the baking sheet in the middle of your oven rack .
#Text=After 5 minutes , stir up the sesame seeds so they do n't burn .
#Text=Then , cook them for another 10-15 minutes .
#Text=Your sesame seeds are thoroughly toasted when the outside is a golden brown color .
#Text=Toast the seeds in your stovetop to ensure they do n’t overcook .
#Text=Place your sesame seeds in a medium-sized saucepan , and set your stovetop temperature to medium .
#Text=Heat up the seeds for 10-15 minutes , and continuously stir the sesame seeds with a mixing spoon as they warm up .
#Text=You should notice a pleasant , nutty aroma as the seeds toast .
#Text=Remove your sesame seeds from the heat when they are golden brown .
#Text=Whether you are using the stovetop or the oven , put your sesame seeds on a plate after they turn a golden brown shade .
#Text=This way , the seeds cool down quicker .
#Text=The golden brown color is a sign that the sesame seeds are toasted properly .
#Text=Avoid overcooking your sesame seeds .
#Text=If your seeds turn medium-dark brown , they are overcooked and will not produce great sesame oil .
#Text=To prevent this , watch your sesame seeds closely throughout the toasting process .
#Text=Remove them from heat as soon as they become a light shade of golden brown .
#Text=If you overcook your sesame seeds , that ’s okay !
#Text=Simply throw them out and try again .
#Text=Blending the Sesame Seeds
#Text=Mix every 1/4 cup ( 59 g ) of sesame seeds with 1 cup ( 237 mL ) of oil .
#Text=Pour your sesame seeds inside a medium or large pot .
#Text=Then , pour in a cooking oil of your choice , based on the amount of sesame seeds you are using .
#Text=You can use either peanut oil , sunflower seed oil , vegetable oil , or coconut oil to help you separate the oil from the sesame seeds .
#Text=If you are using 3 cups ( 710 g ) of sesame seeds , use 12 cups ( 3 L ) of oil .
#Text=All of these work well to help you extract the sesame oil .
#Text=Heat the oil and sesame seeds on your stovetop for 5 minutes or so .
#Text=After you mix together the sesame seeds and cooking oil , use a medium heat setting to warm up the ingredients .
#Text=Warming the sesame seeds in the oil helps extract more of the oil from the seeds .
#Text=Pour the mixture into a blender .
#Text=Once the oil is warmed up , turn off the heat and place your blender in the sink .
#Text=Carefully pour the oil and seeds from the pot into the blender , aiming to get as much as you can inside .
#Text=This way , you can separate the cooking oil from the sesame oil .
#Text=Blend up the sesame seeds until they are broken into small pieces .
#Text=Put the lid on your blender and select a medium chop setting .
#Text=Blend the ingredients for 1-4 minutes or until the seeds are broken down .
#Text=You can stop blending when the seeds look completely crushed up , rather than in granules .
#Text=The ingredients should easily mix together because of the cooking oil .
#Text=If you have difficulty , try stirring the ingredients or using a higher heat setting .
#Text=Let your ingredients sit for 45 minutes to 2 hours .
#Text=After you blend up the ingredients , let it sit in the blender for a while .
#Text=The sesame oil rises to the top , and you can easily separate it after the other oil sinks to the bottom .
#Text=Depending on what oil you used , the sesame oil may separate at different rates .
#Text=For instance , when using peanut oil , it may only take 45 minutes for your oil to separate .
#Text=If using sunflower seed oil , it may take up to 2 hours .
#Text=Separating the Oil
#Text=Pour the mixture through cheesecloth if using an oil other than peanut .
#Text=Pick a small- or medium-sized bowl and stretch the cheesecloth over top .
#Text=Secure the cheesecloth with a string or rubber band .
#Text=By doing this , you easily extract the sesame oil from the cooking oil .
#Text=Using cheesecloth ensures no seeds get inside your oil .
#Text=Do this if you used sunflower oil , coconut oil , or vegetable oil
#Text=Use a bowl to naturally let the oil separate if you 're using peanut oil .
#Text=If you used peanut oil , the separation process is slightly different .
#Text=Simply pour your ingredients into a bowl , and let it sit for at least 45 minutes .
#Text=At this point , the sesame oil naturally raises to the top .
#Text=With peanut oil , you do not need to pour the ingredients through cheesecloth since the oil easily separates on its own .
#Text=Pour the sesame oil into an airtight container using a spoon .
#Text=If you poured the oil through cheesecloth , simply pour the strained sesame oil into a glass jar or plastic container .
#Text=If you are using peanut oil , use a large metal spoon to transport the oil little by little into your container or jar .
#Text=For example , use a liter-sized mason jar with an airtight lid .
#Text=Refrigerate your sesame seed oil to preserve its shelf life .
#Text=If stored in your pantry , sesame oil lasts for 6-8 months .
#Text=However , by putting it in your fridge , you can keep it for up to 2 years .
#Text=If the oil smells sour or tastes bitter , it has spoiled .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Sesame seeds
#Text=Saucepan or baking sheet
#Text=Blender
#Text=Cooking oil
#Text=Spoon
#Text=Bowl
#Text=Cheesecloth
#Text=Storage container
#Text=Refrigerator
#Text=Tips
#Text=Use fresh sesame seeds for best results .
#Text=While you can use any store-bought sesame seeds to make sesame oil , fresh sesame seeds yield the most oil in general .
#Text=Quick Summary
